Most of the comments are dead on. The parent really does not have much of a choice - the expectations and requirements of high school exceed full time. There is no room for other activities.

I personally feel the school load is excessive, but that does not matter. A child gets one chance to complete high school and college in their early years, and you must maximize that effort.

Nate, McLaughlin is the ONLY recent poll showing an Allen lead over Kaine, and it was an internal poll for Allen, which means it wouldnt have been released if the client didnt like the result. So I find it  puzzling why you would give such an outlier poll so out of  keel with the rest of Virginia results such high weighting on the presidential vote. Allen was in need of demonstrating a lead and the assumptions of the electorate that would produce such a lead are so far off from Quinipiac, Marist or even Rasmussen that I find it dubious that they reflect the Virginia electorate. Similarly, why is Gravis polling whose methods appear highly suspect and whose findings skew so consistently towards the GOP side of the electorate weighted so highly?

That's the crew chief? Hoo-hah.

I agree - the photos I take are more for our extended and future family, and take their place alongside preserved family photos dating back well into the nineteenth century. The kids all enjoy photography, and seem to see it as I do...writing them into a family story that goes back generations. It's about belonging and being loved through changing time. And it's grounding and lovely, to see a familiar nose, ears, expression on a great-great-great. We will all one day be gone, but I hope there will always be someone in the family to collect and pass photos on, for future family to peer at and make up stories about, as we do our ancestors. And as a historian I love thinking what all these candids will tell about family life and our culture's reactions to a host of subjects. I hope anyone who values the photos keeps taking them.

It's for statistical reasons. You get a better estimate of the states when you consider the national polls. Each poll has some sampling error, but we know how each state tends to do relative to the national trend. So if we include the national polls in the model, we get a more precise estimate of the probability of winning each state. (Look up Bayesian statistics if you want to learn more.)

The full model (if I understand it correctly) actually doesn't use the national polls except to calibrate the state polls better. So all the estimates published are based on state-by-state predictions, but including the minor tweaks that result from incorporating the information content of the national polls.

Actually, the use of a foreign word in an American crossword makes it an English word, subject to English inflection. This complaint comes up a lot, but always loses to the established convention. (That doesn't mean, btw, that DONNE couldn't have been the answer. It's the editor's choice.)

It's not an unreasonable convention for an English-language puzzle. "Prima donnas" outgoogles "Prime donne."

Jim, once he got to 2-2, Valverde should have grooved two pitches to the outer half of the plate. If Tex hits it on the #4 elevated, so be it, then Ibanez still has to do the same. But maybe he misses it, gets under one, or hits one at a fielder. You know what they say, there is no defense for the walk, and nobody exploits that fact more than the Yankees do.

To respond to Tyler Kepner's tweet praising Teixeira's walk ahead of Ibanez' tying home run: It is much more of a function of criminal pitching by Valverde in that spot. So ahead in the count 0-2, and Valverde starts to nibble. OK, it's still a two run game at than point, and one strike to get. Groove one on the outer half and make him hit his way on. How many HRs does Tex have this post season? And Ibanez? I thought so. The Yankees are always willing to walk. Pitcher can't give it to him.

Thanks for explaining once again, Professor K., that Americans hold significant claims on other countries' assets as well, and that we are not in deep hock to foreigners - yet.   In the case of countries such as China, or in the past, Japan, who have purchased a fairly significant  part of US debt for obvious currency manipulation and trade purposes, maybe someone can explain why we've allow them to get away with it for so long.  Maybe it's a naive question, since they can and do purchase our bonds  in secondary markets (Floyd Norris had an article a couple of years ago about China buying US debt through banks in the UK), although that  problem too could be dealt with - they could be issued non-transferable, couldn't they?  My point is, we not only don't need the Chinese underwriting over a trillion dollars of our debt (maybe it's closer to 2 trillion now, but Professor K said foreign ownership of US debt, overall, was significantly down in recent years), but they'd be doing us a huge service if they ceased doing so.  We have more than enough of our own banks and super wealthy investors parking money in treasuries already, or investing it in risky ventures abroad. The worst that might happen if China stopped buying would be that yields might rise a little, which could draw some capital home if it rose enough; but with ten year bonds selling at historic lows, and at a low spread over shorter term T-bills, the Chinese not buying is not high among my concerns.

Sad though that Rutgers (my alma mater) has gone from $2,000/semester for tuition in the mid 90s to $6,500 semester now http://admissions.rutgers.edu/costs/tuitionandfees.aspx. Let's not forget the surge of protesters attacking US Embassies in Egypt, Yemen, Pakistan, etc. after the release of that vile film. I do believe that clouded the initial reaction to the travesty in Libya. The ledes in all the newspapers tied it to the film. Poor intelligence was coming out of Libya - the FBI couldn't even get to the embassy. It was chaotic. That's why "fog of war" is such an apt term. Susan Rice appeared five days later on the talk shows when the investigation was just beginning.

Mitt Romney immediately seized on the tragedy in Libya and the riots over the film as a campaign issue to advance his credentials on foreign policy experience which we've already seen, since his one overseas misadventure, are hard pressed to fill a thimble.

Mistakes were made, the investigation will continue and blame will be assigned but it will take time, much more than the month that has passed since the attack. It came out last week, that extra security was requested for the embassy in Tripoli, not Benghazi and that House Republicans, including those leading the House investigation, Rep. Issa and Rep. Chavez have consistently voted to cut State's security funding, even in 2012, as had Paul Ryan, which adds another twist to the politics of this. The investigation needs to continue before conclusions can be drawn. The families of the victims are in mourning and out of respect for them, it would be wise to reign in the politics.

I disagree with the author's conflation of white-collar workers and millionaires. Few white-collar workers are millionaires; they are very different classes. If we had more white-collar workers running the government and fewer millionaires, and fewer lawyers, and most importantly fewer legislators and executives who owe their election to money raised from millionaires (and billionaires), there would be hope for the author's vision of the future.

But, let's be realistic. The million/billionaires see no reason to give up the power that lets them set their own tax rates and guide public spending to suit and further enrich themselves. Think of Venice (in the op-ed this same day) or Great Britain, in both of which the barriers to class mobility became more and more severe. The power elite wants to keep the power.

The author has no suggestion for how to stop them. That's the issue. Maybe it will take a revolution -- or it will never happen, and the U.S. will become the Venice or Great Britain of the 21st century.

I think the problem is more endemic than just the discrepancy of wealth between politicians and their constituents.

There is a cultural dividing line as well, between those inside and those outside of the Beltway. The politicians that live and work there for their careers become a part of the Beltway culture, which is cut off from the rest of the country by armies of lobbyists that represent a very limited set of interests of the country at large.

In such isolation, is it any wonder that our representatives grow to relate to each other far more than they do to the rest of us?

Actually, everybody uses the filibuster in the Senate.  The Republicans filibuster Democratic proposals, and the Democrats filibuster Republican proposals.  And all sorts of people threaten to filibuster (the umbrella term for the threats is "holds"), which often results in a bill or nomination dying in committee and never coming to a floor vote.  For presidents, the opposition party is the major hazard,  usually, but they can't always count on their own party, either.

"Representative Paul Ryan, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, said at the debate: “We don’t want to lose the gains we’ve gotten. We want to make sure that the Taliban doesn’t come back in.”

I am reading a book about the killing of President Kennedy and why it matters.
JFK was a realist and a pragmatist. He and his brother Robert were in Vietnam in 1951 when the French were there, and both witnessed the ongoing and humiliating defeat of the French in retaining any hold in Vietnam. From this, John Kennedy learned, and refused even with constant badgering from his Chiefs of Staff, his military generals and the CIA to commit any combat troops to either Laos or Vietnam. He did send support troops though his ultimate goal was to leave Vietnam completely, a goal which was cut short by his assassination.

Those who use absurd rhetoric like Ryan have no conception of the consequences of war, consequences which are often unanticipated, as we have encountered in both Afghanistan and Iraq. With the kind of 'logic' he is uses, it is an open ended argument for endless occupation, with the U.S. never leaving.

These conflicts consume an enormous amount from our country, the lives of young men and women, physically and mentally damaged veterans, and trillions from our Treasury. A vote for Republicans is a vote for more unending conflict and further needless drains on our country. We simply cannot afford four more years of Bush, reincarnated in Romney and Ryan.

And in every reported timeline the wave of demonstrations and violence across the Muslim world are not considered part of the State Department's response. The focus on just Benghazi does not take into account the danger for other consulates and embassies.

Mr. Miller is spot on here.
And unfortunately, the answer to his final question:

"Can’t we just throttle back and wait a reasonable time for answers to surface?"

-- is of course no. Because the state of our politics and the state of our political commentators is to make cheap hay while the sun is shining - and damn the torpedoes and intellectual honesty. It is a travesty, an insult to the electorate, and a tremendously damaging disservice to our country. Were I a bit more prone to vapid, jingoistic language, I'd even call it unpatriotic and un-American.

Three things: People also need to realize that there are two reasons we aren't told everything known.  Public disclosure of classified information remains off limits to government personnel, and troops on the ground have to be considered.  There was certainly less of an OSS presence during WWII than the CIA today.

Your assessment touches on an assumption peculiar to the Beltway bell jar, that Americans are simply too busy, or too ignorant, or too incapable of embracing complex arguments, or simply too ignorant of how the world works to be trusted to deal with evolving scenarios.

Within the GOP politburo and the Obama White House, apparently, albeit certainly for vastly different reasons, the bright boys and girls have embraced the notion that Americans are more comfortable with easily-understood explanations.

I so wish the administration had made it clear to all who were willing to listen that the attack that killed our Libyan ambassador - who seems a contemporary incarnation of T.E. Lawrence without Lawrence’s preternatural good luck - was an unfolding mystery, and that it (the administration believed it likely that the attack was a spin-off of the rage over that abominable low-rent video defaming Islam, but that it was certainly possible the attack was opportunistic or premeditated.

I do not understand the rush to appear in the know. It seems a vanity, not worthy of people entrusted by our vote with governance. I think we all need to slow down.

I was looking recently at photographs of Heartland Americans during World War Two, reading news of the Allied campaign posted in the windows of a small town newspaper. There was plenty of worrisome bad news. Our woes fall far short of theirs. Can’t we just throttle back and wait a reasonable time for answers to surface?
